clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of the Otago Programme Delivered as Home Exercise or Group Exercise
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Controlled Trial of the Effect of Otago Exercise Delivered as Home Exercise or Group Exercise in Fall-prone Older Persons

lead_sponsor.agency: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

collaborator.agency: Norwegian Fund for Postgraduate Training in Physiotherapy

clinical_study.source: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

brief_summary.textblock: The study aims to assess the effect on functional balance of Otago exercise performed as home exercise versus group exercise. The investigators hypothesize that Otago exercise is more effective performed as group exercise than home exercise.

detailed_description.textblock: The study sample is drawn from persons referred to a falls outpatient clinic. Group exercise and home exercise are delivered by trained physiotherapists. Home exercise follows the original Otago exercise protocol. Group exercise is performed twice a week. The length of the intervention period is 3 months. The main outcome measure is the Berg Balance Scale.

primary_outcome.measure: Functional Balance by use of the Berg Balance Scale

secondary_outcome.measure: Fear of falling by the Fall Efficacy Scale International (FES-I), 7 item version
Mobility by the Timed Get up-and-go
Functional leg muscle strength by a Sit-to-stand test
secondary_outcome.description: Number of raise-up trials in 30 sec, picked from the Senior Fitness test

secondary_outcome.measure: Health related quality of life by the Short Formular 36 (SF-36)

arm_group.description: Otago exercise performed as home exercise

intervention.description: Otago exercise performed in groups of 4-8 patients, 2 times a week over 12 weeks
Otago exercise performed as home exercise 3 times a weeks over 12 weeks. Individually tailored physical balance and muscle strength exercise

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- referred to an outpatient falls clinic
- have fallen previous year or have gait or balance problems
Exclusion Criteria:
- Mini Mental Status Examination (MMSE) < 22
- Not able to walk 10 m without support from another person
